indicators.justification:
The The Environmental Ministry has a National Inventory of Greenhouse Gases (INGEI) system that measure the emission information produced in the country(1). They submit this data to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change. The dataset is produced annually. According to the Environmental Ministry, the dataset is published every two years, however, there is no evidence of publication.

Through the World Bank, there is access to CO2 data from 1960 to 2018 (2).

Sources

(1) Environmental Ministry. 2015. National Inventory of Greenhouse Gases of the Dominican Republic - Base Year 2010. http://www.cedaf.org.do/intranet/resena/articulos/2016/gases.pdf
(2) World Bank. https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/EN.ATM.CO2E.PC?locations=DO

evidence.title: National Inventory of Greenhouse Gases of the Dominican Republic - Base Year 2010

indicators.justification:
The climate vulnerability datasets are hosted by the the Ministry of the Environment and Natural Resources (1)and by the  National Statistics Office (2). Most of the mentions datasets are found between both agencies. The datasets were updated at different time, with the most recent being 2020.

The dataset from the Ministry of the Environment and Natural Resources publish environmental statistics on topics such as soil, water, forest, biodiversity, protected areas, coastal marine ecosystems, air, emissions, energy, climate change risk management, as well as those of an economic and social nature related to environmental management, which allow the construction of other statistical operations such as environmental indicators and climate vulnerability information (1). The National Statistic Office publish dataset regarding poverty, gender and marginalized populations (2).

Sources

(1) Ministry of the Environment and Natural Resources. https://ambiente.gob.do/elementor-29987/
(2) National Statistic Office. http://pip.one.gob.do/

evidence.title: data set from Ministry of the Environment and Natural Resources

indicators.justification:
The collection of beneficial ownership of companies is a requirement found on the Law No. 3-02 on Commercial Registry (1). This law requires the collection of this information but doesn't mention the publication. In addition, the General Law of Commercial Companies and Individual Companies of
Limited liability (Law No. 479-08) (2) requires the collection of beneficial ownership data in the entire lifespan of the company. With the introduction of the Law No. 155-17 Against Money Laundering and Terrorism Financing (3) introduces mayor changes to previous law with the transparency of beneficial ownership and forces all company stocks to be issued in registered form. However, a structured open data was not found online. 

Sources

(1) Law No. 3-02 on Commercial Registry. https://www.camarasantodomingo.do/registro-mercantil/Media/assets/documents/base-legal/Ley%203-02%20Registro%20Mercantil.pdf
(2) Law No. 479-08 on Commercial Companies and Individual Companies of
Limited liability. https://dgii.gov.do/legislacion/leyesTributarias/Documents/Otras%20Leyes%20de%20Inter%C3%A9s/479-08.pdf
(3) Law No. 155-17 Against Money Laundering and Terrorism Financing. https://dgii.gov.do/legislacion/leyesTributarias/Documents/Leyes%20de%20Instituciones%20y%20Fondos%20de%20Terceros/155-17.pdf

The data is not found as whole, but information of companies can be search on the National Industrial Property Office (ONAPI)  of the Dominican Republic (1). Through the General Directorate of Internal Taxes (DGII) you can search for companies information through the unique identifier (3).

indicators.justification:
The National Statistics Office (ONE) is the responsible institution and its main objective is to collect, review, prepare and publish national statistics in relation to health, economic, agricultural, commercial, industrial, financial, environmental and social activities of the population.

The ONE provides a civil registration and vital statistics in multiple files, they can all be accessed from the same link (1).

Sources:

(1) ONE Demografic Statistics: vital statistics. https://www.one.gob.do/datos-y-estadisticas/temas/estadisticas-demograficas/estadisticas-vitales/

responses.response_text: Data is available from government, or because of government actions.

Cause of death is standardized to the International Classification of Causes of Death (ICD) or a related, fully interoperable standard.
Mortality information includes data about age, sex and/or gender, geographic location, and cause of death.
Birth information includes data about sex and/or assigned gender of child, gestational age, and birth weight.
Birth information includes data about live-birth order and interval between last and previous live births to mother.
Birth information includes data about place of occurrence, place of usual residence of mother, and month of occurrence.
Birth information includes data about place of registration and month of registration.
Birth information includes data about age, educational attainment, and ethnic and/or national group of mother.
Birth information includes data about age of father and place of usual residence.
Birth information includes data about site of delivery, attendant at birth, and month in which prenatal care began.

indicators.justification:
The government doesn't release the vaccination data. They publish graphs in social network on the progress of the program, but the datasets are not available. External organizations track this publication to create open datasets.

World in Data has an online version of covid vaccination in the Dominican Republic (1). They use official data publish by the Dominican government through their websites and/or social network accounts to aggregate and publish the datasets (3). The Dominican Republic has an official website for the Covid-19 vaccination plan that updates the current number of vaccines dosis applied (3).

Sources

(1) https://ourworldindata.org/covid-vaccinations?country=~DOM
(2) https://ourworldindata.org/covid-vaccinations#source-information-country-by-country
(3) Official Covid-19 Vaccination Program website. https://vacunate.gob.do/

responses.response_text: Data is available, but not as a result of government action.

The data includes information about the sex and/or gender of the people who have been vaccinated.
The data includes information about the disability status of the people who have been vaccinated.
The data includes information about membership in a marginalized population among the people who have been vaccinated.
The data includes information about vaccination for residents of long-term care facilities.
The data includes information about vaccination for residents of prisons and jails.

indicators.justification:
The ministry of environment and natural resources has a 2012 study of land use. The data of the study is not available. The Directorate General for Territorial Planning and Development (DGODT) is the main government agency to provide this data. At the moment of the study, the DGODT doesn't have a web presence. 

Documents with maps that mark the land usage can be found (1)(2).

Sources

(1) Ministry of Environment and Natural Resources. 2012. USE STUDY AND GROUND COVERAGE. http://ambiente.gob.do/wp-content/uploads/2016/12/uso-cobertura-suelo-2012.pdf
(2) Ministry of Economy, Planning and Development and Ministry of the Environment and Natural Resources. 2015. CONSULTATION DOCUMENT NATIONAL TERRITORIAL PLANNING PLAN 2030. https://observatorioplanificacion.cepal.org/sites/default/files/plan/files/CONSULTA%20PLAN%20DE%20OT.pdf

evidence.title: CONSULTATION DOCUMENT NATIONAL MANAGEMENT PLAN TERRITORIAL 2030

indicators.justification:
The Real Estate Registry has exclusive competence to know real estate rights and their registration in the Dominican Republic, from the moment the authorization for the measurement is requested and throughout the life of the property, except for the exceptions provided in the legal framework (1). This sector is regulated by Law 108-05 of Real Estate Registration of March 23, 2005, (modified by Law 51-07 of April 23, 2007) (2), which regulates the registration of real estate rights in all the Dominican territory, implementing the country's real estate advertising system.


Land tenure information could not be found online, this data must exist within the institution but no information on how to access is provided. 

Sources

(1) Real Estate Registry website. https://ri.gob.do/?page_id=474
(2) Law 51-07 National Cadastre. https://www.catastro.gob.do/index.php/marco-legal/category/13-leyes?download=9:ley-51-07

evidence.title: General Directorate of National Land Registry

indicators.justification:
DIGEPRES is the institution in charge of publishing the datasets, they don't specify the license on which the datasets are published. The datasets have different time range, the largest cover a 50 year period. The data is updated to April 2021.

The budget data is structured and separated into multiple datase. On their website they publish the government income (2), expenditure (3), balance (4), consolidate (5) and budget execution (6).

Source

(1) DIGEPRES Website. https://www.digepres.gob.do/
(2) https://www.digepres.gob.do/estadisticas/ingresos/
(3) https://www.digepres.gob.do/estadisticas/gastos/
(4) https://www.digepres.gob.do/estadisticas/balance/
(5) https://www.digepres.gob.do/estadisticas/consolidado/
(6) https://www.digepres.gob.do/estadisticas-ejecucion-presupuestaria/

There is structured data about government budget execution or spending, in gross terms and on an accrual basis, including spending in annual and multi-annual investment projects.
There is structured data about the government's extrabudgetary funds spending, in gross terms and on an accrual basis.
There is structured data about the government's social security spending, in gross terms and on an accrual basis.
There is structured data about public corporations' spending, in gross terms and on an accrual basis.

Budget entries have economic classifications to an internationally agreed standard.
Budget entries have functional classifications to an internationally agreed standard.
Budget entries have program classifications according to an internationally agreed standard.
Information about individual financial transactions or expenditures is available at the most disaggregated level of the economic classification level.

The data contains common identifiers to connect budget and budget performance data.
The data contains identifiers that can be used to connect budget data with data on major projects (e.g., infrastructure construction) and procurement processes.

indicators.justification:
The Law No. 311-14 creates the framework that requires public officers to declare their assets and other financial instruments (1). The law establishes the required mechanism to report, the Account Chamber is responsable to track public offices declarations. The dataset is available on their portal (2). The search tools allows for citizens to search all public officers and their assets declaration. The data can be downloaded for each individual officer.

Sources

(1) Law No. 311-14 on a National Automated and Uniform System of Affidavits of Assets of Public Officials and Servants. https://www.sismap.gob.do/Municipal/uploads/Marco%20Legal/Otras/8-Ley%20311-14%20sobre%20Declarac%20Jurada%20Patrimonio.pdf
(2) Account Chamber declaration portal. https://djurada.camaradecuentas.gob.do/DJP_OJO_CIUDADANO/pgReportesDJPExternos.aspx

indicators.justification:
The Central Electoral Board (JCE) publish the financial information for each presidential candidate by political party. The information includes all the incomes and expenses inquired by the campaign (1). This is a requirement from the Law No. 33-18 on Parties groups and Political movements is for all political parties and movements in the Dominican Republic (2). 

Sources

(1) JCE dataset on presidential candidate campaign expenditure. https://jce.gob.do/portaltransparencia/Informes-de-Candidatos

indicators.justification:
The General Directorate of Government Ethics and Integrity has among its attributions the rectory of Law 200-04 (1), its application Regulations approved by Decree 130-05 (2), for which, in coordination with other public entities, it has designed a single platform for the application of the information by the citizen, which is called the Single Portal of Request for Access to Public Information (SAIP). The SAIP provides the dataset, and provides tools to provide general information from the data (3).

Sources

The General Directorate of Public Procurement (DGCP), a dependency of the Ministry of Finance, is the responsible for these datasets (1). The datasets are machine readable and open. The dataset follows the Open Contracting Data Standard (OCDS) (2)(3). The data is available from 2018 to 2020.

indicators.justification:
The norm that regulates Open Data has two chapters focused on reusable data (Chapter 3 and 4) (1). Chapter 3 is about identifying and categorizing reusable data, where chapter 4 focus on the structure of reusable data.

The government has few activities promoting the usage of open data. Most of the activities promoted by  universities or private organizations (2)(3).

There is a National Prize for Data Journalism, the first event was on 2019 and the second on 2021 (4).  The prize is founded by he General Directorate of Government Ethics and Integrity (DIGEIG) and the Presidential Office for ICT (OPTIC) (5)(6).

Sources

(1) OPTIC. 2014. Standard on the Publication of Open Data of the Dominican Government NORTIC A3:2014. https://ogtic.gob.do/wp-content/uploads/2019/07/NORTIC-A3-2014.pdf
(2) https://ctc.edu.do/2019/09/vicepresidencia-google-org-y-el-instituto-abierto-del-caribe-formaran-en-tecnologia-a-jovenes-vulnerables/
(3) https://pciudadana.org/realizan-primer-hackathon-virtual-en-rd-para-luchar-contra-covid-19/
(4) https://hoy.com.do/digeig-y-optic-celebran-dia-internacional-de-los-datos-abiertos/
(5) https://eldinero.com.do/79307/director-de-eldinero-gana-primer-lugar-en-el-premio-nacional-de-periodismo-de-datos/
(6) https://listindiario.com/la-vida/2020/02/11/603980/destacan-la-importancia-de-que-periodistas-hagan-uso-del-analisis-de-datos-abiertos

indicators.justification:
The General Directorate of Government Ethics and Integrity (DIGEIG) is the government institution responsible for the Open Data Initiative. This institutions has the organization chart to support and maintain the initiative (1). For technical aspects of the platform  DIGEIG has the support of the Presidential Office for ICT (OPTIC). The two institutions have develop the Standard for Publishing Open Government Data in the Dominican Republic (2)(3) and a draft policy in 2021 (4)

Sources

(1) DIGEIG Payroll https://digeig.gob.do/transparencia/phocadownload/RecursosHumanos/Nomina/2021/enero/Nomina%20Enero%202021%20%20Empleados%20fijos.pdf

indicators.justification:
In the national open data portal, approximately 10 municipalities have dedicated data catalogs (1). The largest municipalities have some datasets published on their websites (2)(3). No evidence could be found of a municipal government in the country presenting its own open data initiative.

Sources

(1) Open Data Portal, filter by municipalities. http://datos.gob.do/organization?q=ayuntamiento&sort=name+asc

indicators.justification:
The Open Data Policy of the Dominican Republic (Draft), Article 20,"Capacity building on Open Data" promotes the creation of a curriculum for training civil servants on matters related to Data (1). The responsibilities are transferred to Technological Institute of the Americas (ITLA)(2) and National Institute of Public Administration (INAP)(3).

ITLA has different courses and technical degrees related to data. These are open to the general population (4)(5).

Sources

(1) DIGEIG and OGTIC. 2021. Open Data Policy of the Dominican Republic (Draft). https://www.digeig.gob.do/wp-content/uploads/2021/03/BORRADOR-Politica-de-Datos-Abiertos-RDO-pfd.pdf
(2) ITLA website. https://itla.edu.do/
(3) INAP website. https://inapvirtual.edu.do/
(4) ITLA Data analytics and science technical program. https://itla.edu.do/analitica-y-ciencia-de-los-datos/
(5) ITLA Artificial Inteligence technical program. https://itla.edu.do/tecnologia-en-inteligencia-artificial/

indicators.justification: No common identifiers were found on the datasets.

responses.response_text: The datasets do not share common identifiers.
responses.subquestion_text: There is evidence that datasets share common identifiers.
The key datasets for this theme share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.
The different political integrity datasets use common identifiers for public officials.
Lobbying data and political finance data share common identifiers for lobbyist clients and party and campaign donors.
Lobbying registers and public consultation data use common identifiers for regulations.
Asset declarations and political finance disclosures share common identifiers for interests, assets, and liabilities.
The various datasets share common identifiers for legal persons associated with donations, interests, assets, liabilities, and lobbying activities.
The key datasets for the political integrity and company information modules share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.
The key datasets for the political integrity and land modules share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.
The key datasets for the political integrity and public finance modules share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.
The key datasets for the political integrity and public procurement modules share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.

responses.response_text: There is no consistency of identifiers or identification systems.

indicators.justification:
Three laws regulate the formation of societies in the Dominican Republic. The collection of beneficial ownership of companies is a requirement found on the Law No. 3-02 on Commercial Registry (1). This law requires the collection of this information but doesn't mention the publication. In addition, the General Law of Commercial Companies and Individual Companies of
Limited liability (Law No. 479-08) (2) requires the collection of beneficial ownership data in the entire lifespan of the company. With the introduction of the Law No. 155-17 Against Money Laundering and Terrorism Financing (3) introduces mayor changes to previous law with the transparency of beneficial ownership and forces all company stocks to be issued in registered form.

Sources

(1) Law No. 3-02 on Commercial Registry. https://www.camarasantodomingo.do/registro-mercantil/Media/assets/documents/base-legal/Ley%203-02%20Registro%20Mercantil.pdf
(2) Law No. 479-08 on Commercial Companies and Individual Companies of
Limited liability. https://dgii.gov.do/legislacion/leyesTributarias/Documents/Otras%20Leyes%20de%20Inter%C3%A9s/479-08.pdf
(3) Law No. 155-17 Against Money Laundering and Terrorism Financing. https://dgii.gov.do/legislacion/leyesTributarias/Documents/Leyes%20de%20Instituciones%20y%20Fondos%20de%20Terceros/155-17.pdf

indicators.justification:
The Presidential Offices of Information and Communication Technologies (OPTIC) and the General Directorate of Government Ethics and Integrity (DIGEIG) developed the Standard for Publishing Open Government Data in the Dominican Republic (NORTIC A3) in 2014 (1) and an update in 2018 (2). These norms have no mention in with guidances for data accessibility to people with disability. In addition, no norms or regulations could be found with guidances for accessibility to people with disability.

In a draft version of a new Open Data Policies of the Dominican Republic to update the current norms and standards (3), there was no mention of data accessibility to people with disability.

Sources

(1) OPTIC. 2014. Standard on the Publication of Open Data of the Dominican Government NORTIC A3:2014. https://ogtic.gob.do/wp-content/uploads/2019/07/NORTIC-A3-2014.pdf
(2) OPTIC. 2018. Guide for the Use of the Open Data Portal of the Dominican Government NORTIC A3:2018. https://ogtic.gob.do/wp-content/uploads/2019/07/NORTIC-A3-2018.pdf
(3) DIGEIG & OGTIC. 2021. DRAFT OPEN DATA POLICY OF THE DOMINICAN REPUBLIC. https://www.digeig.gob.do/wp-content/uploads/2021/03/BORRADOR-Politica-de-Datos-Abiertos-RDO-pfd.pdf

indicators.justification:
The Presidential Offices of Information and Communication Technologies (OPTIC) and the General Directorate of Government Ethics and Integrity (DIGEIG) developed the Standard for Publishing Open Government Data in the Dominican Republic (NORTIC A3) in 2014 (1) and an update in 2018 (2).

NORTIC A3 are norms, not a law. The norms were developed by to organizations that belong to the executive power, but the norms are intended for all government institutions. These norms establish the mechanisms for data management and publication.

The norms could improve in data management aspects, it only  emphases on metadata, neglecting other aspects of data management.

Sources

(1) OPTIC. 2014. Standard on the Publication of Open Data of the Dominican Government NORTIC A3:2014. https://ogtic.gob.do/wp-content/uploads/2019/07/NORTIC-A3-2014.pdf
(2) OPTIC. 2018. Guide for the Use of the Open Data Portal of the Dominican Government NORTIC A3:2018. https://ogtic.gob.do/wp-content/uploads/2019/07/NORTIC-A3-2018.pdf

responses.response_text: A framework exists but lacks full force of law.
responses.subquestion_text: What is the nature of the framework?
There are minimum standards for metadata when government data is catalogued or published.
There is a standardised process for publishing and updating published government data.
There are technical standards, including common data models, codelists, and identifiers for management and publication of government data.
There are clearly documented quality control processes for government data.
There are clearly documented processes for soliciting and integrating feedback from external users to improve data quality.

responses.response_text: The data management approaches assessed generally apply across the whole public sector.
responses.subquestion_text: How broadly is good data management practice established?

indicators.justification:
The Presidential Offices of Information and Communication Technologies (OPTIC) and the General Directorate of Government Ethics and Integrity (DIGEIG) developed the Standard for Publishing Open Government Data in the Dominican Republic (NORTIC A3) in 2014 (1) and an update in 2018 (2).

NORTIC A3:2014 and NORTIC A3:2018 are norms, not laws. The norms were developed by two organizations that belong to the executive power. These norms are intended for all government institutions and they establish the mechanisms for data sharing.

Sources

(1) OPTIC. 2014. Standard on the Publication of Open Data of the Dominican Government NORTIC A3:2014. https://ogtic.gob.do/wp-content/uploads/2019/07/NORTIC-A3-2014.pdf
(2) OPTIC. 2018. Guide for the Use of the Open Data Portal of the Dominican Government NORTIC A3:2018. https://ogtic.gob.do/wp-content/uploads/2019/07/NORTIC-A3-2018.pdf

responses.subquestion_text: What is the nature of the framework?
The framework covers data sharing within government.
The framework covers how government should share data with other sectors.
The framework covers data sharing from other sectors to government.
The framework covers data sharing within the private sector.
The framework explicitly focuses on artificial intelligence uses of data.

indicators.justification:
The Dominican Constitution mentions the protection of data and citizens privacy (1). The Law No. 172-13 on comprehensive protection of personal data provides the legal framework for protecting data and privacy (2). 

The operational part of the law focuses on the services provided by Credit Information Societies, the law is weak in establishing responsibilities of data protection outside of the financial sector (3).

Sources
(1) Dominican Constitution. 2010. https://dominicana.gob.do/index.php/recursos/2014-12-16-21-02-56/category/3-constitucion-y-leyes-rd?download=22:constitucion-de-la-republica-2010 
(2) Law No. 172-13 on comprehensive protection of personal data. 2013. https://indotel.gob.do/media/6200/ley_172_13.pdf
(3) Pellerano & Herrera, Law No. 172-13 on comprehensive protection of personal data 2013, http://www.phlaw.com/imagen?file=articulos/420/law-no-172-13-on-comprehensive-protection-personal-data

The framework requires data controllers to notify an appropriate authority of data breaches.
Frameworks explicitly cover the protection of location-related data.

indicators.justification:
The Presidential Offices of Information and Communication Technologies (OPTIC) and the General Directorate of Government Ethics and Integrity (DIGEIG) developed the Standard for Publishing Open Government Data in the Dominican Republic (NORTIC A3) in 2014 (1) and an update in 2018 (2). These norms that regulates Open Data do not explicitly mention the language of publication. In the Dominican Republic, Spanish is the national and official language (3). 

Sources

(1) OPTIC. 2014. Standard on the Publication of Open Data of the Dominican Government NORTIC A3:2014. https://ogtic.gob.do/wp-content/uploads/2019/07/NORTIC-A3-2014.pdf
(2) OPTIC. 2018. Guide for the Use of the Open Data Portal of the Dominican Government NORTIC A3:2018. https://ogtic.gob.do/wp-content/uploads/2019/07/NORTIC-A3-2018.pdf
(3) https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dominican_Republic

indicators.justification:
the Presidential Office for ICT (OPTIC) and the General Directorate of Government Ethics and Integrity (DIGEIG) have developed Standards on Information Technology and Communication for the Publication of Open Government Data (NORTIC A3) (1)(2). The NORTIC standard was approved in 2014 (1) and updated in 2018 (2), this standard is still used as the guideline for Open Government Data. Starting on march 2021, OPTIC and  DIGEIG opened a citizen consultations for the Open Data Policies of the Dominican Republic to update the current norms and standards (3). These are the main documents that define the framework used in the Dominican Republic for publishing Open Data

Sources

(1) OPTIC. 2014. Standard on the Publication of Open Data of the Dominican Government NORTIC A3:2014. https://ogtic.gob.do/wp-content/uploads/2019/07/NORTIC-A3-2014.pdf
(2) OPTIC. 2018. Guide for the Use of the Open Data Portal of the Dominican Government NORTIC A3:2018. https://ogtic.gob.do/wp-content/uploads/2019/07/NORTIC-A3-2018.pdf
(3) DIGEIG & OGTIC. 2021. DRAFT OPEN DATA POLICY OF THE DOMINICAN REPUBLIC. https://www.digeig.gob.do/wp-content/uploads/2021/03/BORRADOR-Politica-de-Datos-Abiertos-RDO-pfd.pdf

indicators.justification:
The General Budget Directorate (DIGEPRES) is the responsible agency in this area (1). The legal framework of this directorate is govern by multiple laws. The Law No. 101-79 indicates that the directorate has to submit  monthly reports income and expenses of the government in Article 1-3 (2).

The Organic Budget for the Public Sector Law (Law No. 423-06), in Article 11 establish the principle of transparency and publication (3). It implies the guarantee of periodic public communication and free access to information by the citizenship on budget management.

Source

(1) DIGEPRES Website. https://www.digepres.gob.do/
(2) Law No. 101-79 on the obligation to submit monthly reports Income and Expenses. https://www.digepres.gob.do/transparencia/wp-content/uploads/2013/05/2.8.1.1.5-LEY-101-79-SOBRE-OBLIGATORIEDAD-DE-PRESENTAR-REPORTES-MENSUALES-INGRESOS-Y-EGRESOS.pdf
(3) Law No. 423-06 The Organic Budget for the Public Sector Law. https://www.digepres.gob.do/transparencia/wp-content/uploads/2013/07/Ley-Num-423-06-de-2006.pdf

indicators.justification:
The Law No. 311-14 creates the framework that requires public officers to declare their assets and other financial instruments (1). The law establishes the requires mechanism to report, the penalties if public officers do not comply and institutions that have to validate the information.


Sources

(1) Law No. 311-14 on a National Automated and Uniform System of Affidavits of Assets of Public Officials and Servants. https://www.sismap.gob.do/Municipal/uploads/Marco%20Legal/Otras/8-Ley%20311-14%20sobre%20Declarac%20Jurada%20Patrimonio.pdf

The framework requires collecting specific information on assets and liabilities.

The framework requires disclosure of income and assets held by a public official's spouse, family members, or other intimates.

indicators.justification:
As of 2021, the Dominican Republic doesn't have a legal framework to regulate lobbying (1).

Sources

(1) https://eldinero.com.do/134482/regular-el-cabildeo-en-republica-dominicana/

evidence.title: News Article on Lobbying in the DR

responses.subquestion_text: Are there laws, policies, or regulations requiring collection or publication of this information in any form?

responses.response_text: There is no mention of data or the publication of data in relevant laws, policies, or guidance.
responses.subquestion_text: Do relevant laws, policies, regulations, or guidance discuss the publication of open data?
The framework contains clear and unambiguous definitions of lobbyists, lobbying clients, lobbying activities, and public officials.
The framework requires the collection and publication of the identities of lobbyists, lobbyist clients, and public officials who engage with lobbyists.
The framework requires the collection and publication of information on lobbyists' goals for lobbying activities.
The framework requires the collection and publication of information on timing of lobbying activities.
The framework requires the collection and publication of information on topics of lobbying activities.
The framework requires the collection and publication of information on how much money is spent on lobbying activities.
The rules/guidance empower an agency or official to ensure the accurate and timely collection and publication of required data.
The framework requires a verification process.
The rules/guidance require that data is regularly updated.

indicators.justification:
The Law No. 33-18 is the legal framework that regulates political parties and movements. This law indicates that parties finances has to be provided to the National Election Committee annually with the accounting specifications required (1). The framework doesn't mention that this data is public or open. In addition, the framework doesn't mention any structured format.

Sources

(1) Law No. 33-18 on Parties groups and Political movements. https://jce.gob.do/DesktopModules/Bring2mind/DMX/Download.aspx?EntryId=12323&Command=Core_Download&language=es-ES&PortalId=1&TabId=192

The framework contains clear and unambiguous definitions of campaigning activities of parties, candidates, and third parties.

responses.response_text: The framework requires the public disclosure of the identity of every donor.

The framework requires regular updates, including updates in conjunction with campaigns and defined campaign schedules.

indicators.justification:
Law No. 107-13 on the Rights of People in their Relationships with the Administration and Administrative Procedure. Chapter two provides the common rules for the preparation of administrative rules and plans. In Article 31 a section indicates the participation of the general public, regardless of whether or not it is directly affected by the draft regulatory text, plan or program, must be guaranteed before final approval, unless otherwise stated in the law (1).

Sources

(1) Law No. 107-13 on the Rights of People in their Relationships with the Administration and Administrative Procedure. https://observatorioserviciospublicos.gob.do/publicaciones/miscelaneos/ley_107_13.pdf

responses.subquestion_text: Are there laws, policies, or regulations requiring collection or publication of this information in any form?

The framework requires the publication of notice of intent in advance of public consultation processes.
The framework requires the publication of proposed regulations.
The framework requires the timely publication of a full set of public comments generated through public consultation processes.
The framework requires reasoned responses to be published alongside comments.
The framework requires the publication of final regulations and justification.
The framework requires the publication of challenges to laws and regulations that have undergone public consultation processes, as well as their results.
The rules/guidance empower an agency or official to ensure the accurate and timely collection and publication of required data.

indicators.justification:
Law No. 200-04 a General Law of Free Access to Public Information. The law establishes that everyone has the right to request and receive complete, truthful, adequate and timely, of any organ of the Dominican State, and of all corporations, public limited companies or joint stock companies with state participation (1). After the law, a decree was published to establish the regulations from Law No. 200-04 (2).

Sources

(1) Law No. 200-04 a General Law of Free Access to Public Information. https://www.micm.gob.do/images/pdf/transparencia/leyes/Ley-200-04.pdf
(2) Decree 130-05 approves the Regulations of the General Law of Free Access to Public Information.  https://sb.gob.do/sites/default/files/nuevosdocumentos/DECRETO-130-05.pdf

responses.subquestion_text: Are there laws, policies, or regulations requiring collection or publication of this information in any form?

responses.response_text: Requirements to publish data are set out in non-binding policy or guidance.
responses.subquestion_text: Do relevant laws, policies, regulations, or guidance discuss the publication of open data?
The framework requires the collection and publication of data regarding the number of requests submitted and processed.
The framework requires the collection and publication of data regarding how long it took the relevant government agency or agencies to fill requests.
The framework requires the collection and publication of data regarding material withheld and the reasons for withholding it.
The framework requires the collection and publication of data regarding appeals to RTI determinations and their results.
The framework requires that information is linked to the relevant agency, department, or other governmental entity.
The rules/guidance empower an agency or official to ensure the accurate and timely collection and publication of required data.
The framework requires a verification process.
The rules/guidance require that data is regularly updated.
The rules/guidance support the collection of structured data.

responses.response_text: The framework covers the entire public sector.
responses.subquestion_text: How comprehensive, in terms of jurisdiction, is the framework assessed for this question?

indicators.justification:
An international website provides a service that use open company data to support due diligence (1). The service obtains the information from the the National Industrial Property Office (ONAPI) (2). In the newspaper some article use this website as a tool to report on people accused of corruption or money laundering (3).

Sources

(1) Open Corporate, Dominican Chapter. https://opencorporates.com/companies/do  
(2) ONAPI search portal. https://www.onapi.gov.do/busquedas/index.html#/
(3) https://listindiario.com/la-republica/2021/05/20/671250/agregan-mas-implicados-en-expediente-de-gutierrez

indicators.justification:
The Real Estate Registry has exclusive competence to know real estate rights and their registration in the Dominican Republic, from the moment the authorization for the measurement is requested and throughout the life of the property, except for the exceptions provided in the legal framework (1). This sector is regulated by Law 108-05 of Real Estate Registration of March 23, 2005, (modified by Law 51-07 of April 23, 2007) (2), which regulates the registration of real estate rights in all the Dominican territory, implementing the country's real estate advertising system.


There are no evidence of using land data for the benefit of the community.

Sources

(1) Real Estate Registry website. https://ri.gob.do/?page_id=474
(2) Law 51-07 National Cadastre. https://www.catastro.gob.do/index.php/marco-legal/category/13-leyes?download=9:ley-51-07

indicators.justification:
The media regularly uses political integrity data to report abuse by the government or other public actors (1)(2). Most of the impact comes from the usage of political integrity data by the media. They regularly expose their findings and keep a track of the government and political parties doing (3). During government transition, they analyze how much the wealth incremented or the difference in assets (4). There are different evidences on media using political integrity during the political campaigns, to understand how political candidates are being financed.

Sources

(1) https://n.com.do/2019/02/10/nuria-piera-intimamos-legalmente-a-oisoe-por-violar-la-ley-de-libre-acceso-a-la-informacion-publica/
(2) https://elinformeconaliciaortega.com/declaraciones-juradas-de-bienes-el-secreto-mejor-guardado-de-decenas-de-instituciones/
(3) https://ensegundos.do/2021/02/02/alicia-ortega-trata-de-aclarar-el-maco-en-los-reportes-de-muertes-por-covid-19/
(4)https://www.diariolibre.com/actualidad/el-informe-con-alicia-ortega-dice-que-etica-gubernamental-investigo-lo-que-gonzalo-queria-NO20593860

indicators.justification:
The General Directorate of Public Procurement (DGCP) has multiple dashboards providing interesting use of the procurement dataset (1). Also the The General Budget Directorate (DIGEPRES) has dashboard that present useful insight from the procurement dataset (2). No evidence could be found of civil or private use of the dataset.

Sources

(1) DGCP dashboards. https://www.dgcp.gob.do/datos-abiertos/visualizaciones/
(2) DIGEPRES Dashboards. https://mapa-covid.transparenciafiscal.gob.do/covid/FichaCovid

responses.response_text: There is evidence of multiple different uses involving different organisations.

There is evidence of government procurement data being presented through data-driven dashboards.
There is evidence of government procurement data being used for red flag analysis.
There is evidence that government procurement data is being analyzed to improve access to procurement opportunities for marginalized groups.
There is evidence of government procurement data being analysed to support sustainable / environmental procurement.
There are examples of government using data in these ways.
There are examples of civil society using data in these ways.
There is evidence of private sector using data in this way
At least one of the examples cited appears to make use of open procurement data.
At least one of the examples identified makes use of open beneficial ownership data.
At least one of the examples identified describes using artificial Intelligence or machine learning to process data
There is evidence that these uses have had or are having meaningful positive impacts.
